examples.sentence: する verbs (料理する → 料理ができる)
Very formal → ことができる
Skill/ability → potential form or ことができる
Natural sense → 見える/聞こえる
Yes → できる (料理ができる)
Potential Form - Conjugation and basic usage
ことができる - Formal ability expression
〜やすい/〜にくい - Easy/hard to do
〜ようになる - Come to be able to
見える/聞こえる - Natural visibility/audibility

sections.heading: Understanding the Difference
sections.content:
Japanese has multiple ways to express "can," each with subtle differences in meaning and usage:

| Expression | Focus | Usage | | ------------------ | ----------------------- | -------------- | | Potential form | Natural ability/skill | Most common | | ことができる | Formal ability | Written/formal | | できる | General capability | する verbs | | 〜得る (うる/える) | Theoretical possibility | Formal/written |

children.heading: Focus: Learned skills and capabilities
children.content: 日本語が話せます "I can speak Japanese" (I have the skill) 泳げる "I can swim" (I have the ability) ピアノが弾ける "I can play piano" (I learned how)

children.heading: Best for:
children.content: Acquired skills Physical abilities Habitual capabilities Natural conversation

sections.heading: ことができる: Formal Ability

children.heading: Focus: Accomplishment or possibility
children.content: 日本語を話すことができます "I am able to speak Japanese" (More formal statement) ついに完成させることができた "I was finally able to complete it" (Emphasizes achievement)

children.heading: Best for:
children.content: Formal situations Written Japanese Emphasizing achievement Polite expressions

children.heading: Focus: General skill or possibility
children.content: 料理ができます "I can cook" (General ability) 今日はできません "I can't today" (Not possible today) 彼はなんでもできる "He can do anything" (General capability)

children.heading: Best for:
children.content: する verbs (料理する → 料理ができる) General statements Possibility (not specific skills)

children.heading: Situational (right now, today)
children.content:
Often uses potential form or できる:

今日は早く帰れます "I can go home early today" (Circumstance allows it) 明日は会えません "I can't meet tomorrow" (Schedule doesn't permit) 今ならできる "I can do it now" (Current situation allows)

children.heading: Inherent (permanent skill)
children.content:
Can use any form, but potential is most natural:

日本語が話せます "I can speak Japanese" (I have the skill) 泳げる "I can swim" (I know how)

children.heading: Pure ability: Use potential form
children.content: 漢字が読める "I can read kanji" (I have the skill)

children.heading: Permission: Use てもいい
children.content: ここで写真を撮ってもいいですか？ "May I take photos here?" (Asking permission) Not: ここで写真が撮れますか？ ⚠️ (This asks about physical possibility, not permission)

children.heading: Both ability AND permission:
children.content:
Sometimes potential form can imply both:

ここで泳げますか？ "Can you swim here?" Could mean: Is swimming possible/allowed here?

children.heading: Physical capability
children.content: 重い物が持てる "I can lift heavy things" (Physical strength) 100メートル走れる "I can run 100 meters" (Physical stamina) 暗い所でも見える "I can see even in dark places" (Natural ability)

children.heading: Learned skill
children.content: ピアノが弾ける "I can play piano" (Learned skill) プログラミングができる "I can program" (Learned skill) 車が運転できる "I can drive" (Learned skill)

children.heading: "Can speak Japanese"
children.content:
Most natural (conversation):

日本語が話せます Potential form - casual, natural

Formal (business/writing):

日本語を話すことができます ことができる - polite, formal

General (skill mention):

日本語ができます できる - general ability

children.heading: "Can swim"
children.content:
Skill you have:

泳げます Potential form

Right now possibility:

今日は泳げます "I can swim today" Potential form (circumstance)

Achievement:

ついに25メートル泳ぐことができた "I was finally able to swim 25 meters" ことができる (emphasis on achievement)

children.heading: 見える (mieru) - Can see/is visible
children.content:
Natural visibility:

窓から海が見える "The ocean is visible from the window" (It's naturally there to see)

Not the potential form of 見る!

children.heading: 見られる (mirareru) - Can watch/see
children.content:
Ability to see/watch:

この映画が見られますか？ "Can you watch this movie?" (Do you have ability/permission?)

This IS the potential form of 見る.

children.heading: 聞こえる (kikoeru) - Can hear/is audible
children.content:
Natural audibility:

音楽が聞こえる "I can hear music" (Sound reaches my ears naturally)

children.heading: 聞ける (kikeru) - Can listen/ask
children.content:
Ability to listen:

このラジオが聞けますか？ "Can you listen to this radio?" (Ability/possibility to listen)

children.heading: 〜得る (うる/える) - Theoretical possibility
children.content:
Formal, written:

そのようなことはあり得る "Such a thing is possible" (Theoretically possible) 考え得る全ての方法 "All conceivable methods" (All methods one could think of)

Not common in speech!

children.heading: Potential form - Actual possibility
children.content: 明日は行けます "I can go tomorrow" (Actually possible for me) それはできる "That can be done" (Practically possible)

children.heading: できる with modifiers
children.content: なかなかできない "It's difficult / I can't quite do it" 簡単にできる "I can do it easily" すぐにできる "I can do it right away"

children.heading: Potential with effort phrases
children.content: 頑張れば話せるようになる "If you try hard, you'll be able to speak" 練習すれば弾けるようになる "With practice, you'll be able to play"

children.heading: Mistake 1: Using potential for permission
children.content: Wrong context: ここで食べられますか？ ⚠️ For permission: ここで食べてもいいですか？ ✓ "May I eat here?" Potential is OK if asking about rules: ここで食べられますか？ ✓ "Is eating allowed here?" / "Can one eat here?"

children.heading: Mistake 2: Overusing ことができる in casual speech
children.content: Unnatural: 泳ぐことができる？ ⚠️ Natural: 泳げる？ ✓ "Can you swim?"

children.heading: Mistake 3: Confusing 見える with 見られる
children.content: 見える = visible (no volition) 窓から海が見える ✓ "The ocean is visible from the window" 見られる = can watch (with volition) 映画が見られる ✓ "Can watch a movie"

children.heading: Mistake 4: Wrong particle
children.content: Wrong: 日本語を話せます ❌ Right: 日本語が話せます ✓ "I can speak Japanese" But OK: 日本語を話すことができます ✓

sections.heading: Nuance Comparison Chart
sections.content: | Situation | Best Choice | Example | | ------------------ | ------------ | ---------------------- | | Casual skill | Potential | 泳げる | | Formal statement | ことができる | 泳ぐことができます | | Achievement | ことができる | ついに泳ぐことができた | | する verbs | できる | 料理ができる | | Natural visibility | 見える | 海が見える | | Permission | てもいい | 泳いでもいい | | Theoretical | 〜得る | あり得る |

children.heading: Scenario 1: Job Interview
children.content: Less natural: 日本語が話せます ⚠️ Better: 日本語を話すことができます ✓ "I can speak Japanese" (Formal situation → use ことができる)

children.heading: Scenario 2: Chatting with Friends
children.content: Unnatural: 泳ぐことができる？ ⚠️ Natural: 泳げる？ ✓ "Can you swim?" (Casual → use potential form)

children.heading: Scenario 3: Achievement
children.content: Good: ついに合格できた ✓ Better: ついに合格することができた ✓ "I was finally able to pass" (Achievement → ことができる emphasizes it)

children.heading: Scenario 4: Restaurant
children.content: For permission: ここで食べてもいいですか？ ✓ "May I eat here?" For possibility: ここで食べられますか？ ✓ "Is eating possible here?" Different meanings!

children.heading: Learning progression
children.content: 今は話せません "I can't speak now" 少し話せるようになりました "I've become able to speak a little" 今は話せます "I can speak now"

children.heading: Using なる (become)
children.content: 話せるようになる "Become able to speak" できるようになる "Become able to do" 見えるようになる "Become able to see"

children.heading: 見られる can mean three things:
children.content:
1. Potential (can see/watch):

この映画は見られますか？ "Can you watch this movie?"

2. Passive (is seen):

人に見られた "I was seen by someone"

3. Respect (honorific watch):

先生がテレビを見られる "The teacher watches TV"

Context makes it clear!

sections.heading: Summary Table
sections.content: | Expression | Formality | Usage | Example | | ---------------- | ------------- | ------------------ | ------------------------ | | 話せる | Casual-Polite | Natural speech | 日本語が話せる | | 話すことができる | Formal | Written/formal | 日本語を話すことができる | | 日本語ができる | Neutral | General ability | 日本語ができる | | 見える | Neutral | Natural visibility | 海が見える | | 聞こえる | Neutral | Natural audibility | 音楽が聞こえる | | 〜得る | Very formal | Theoretical | あり得る |

children.heading: Ask yourself:
children.content:
1. How formal is the situation?

Very formal → ことができる Normal/casual → potential form

2. What are you expressing?

Skill/ability → potential form or ことができる Permission → てもいい Natural sense → 見える/聞こえる General capability → できる

3. Is it a する verb?

Yes → できる (料理ができる) No → potential form (泳げる)

4. Are you emphasizing achievement?

Yes → ことができる No → potential form

children.heading: Basic Choice
children.content: Casual: 日本語が話せる Formal: 日本語を話すことができます General: 日本語ができる All mean: "I can speak Japanese"

children.heading: Natural Senses
children.content: 海が見える (not 見られる for visibility) "The ocean is visible" 音が聞こえる (not 聞ける for natural hearing) "I can hear a sound"

children.heading: Achievement
children.content: ついに完成させることができました "I was finally able to complete it" (Emphasizes the achievement)

children.heading: Permission
children.content: 写真を撮ってもいいですか？ "May I take photos?" (Asking permission, not ability)

children.heading: Potential form: More direct
children.content: 明日行ける "I can go tomorrow" (Direct statement of ability)

children.heading: ことができる: More tentative/polite
children.content: 明日行くことができます "I am able to go tomorrow" (More formal, polite statement)

children.heading: できる: Most general
children.content: 明日ならできる "If it's tomorrow, I can (do it)" (General possibility)

sections.heading: Related Grammar Points
sections.content: Potential Form - Conjugation and basic usage ことができる - Formal ability expression 〜やすい/〜にくい - Easy/hard to do 〜得る (うる/える) - Theoretical possibility 〜ようになる - Come to be able to Permission (てもいい) - May/can (permission) 見える/聞こえる - Natural visibility/audibility
